Questions: Will your family’s relationships become more strained as time goes on?
MultipleChoice1: You think that your family is likely to
mc1a: Talk to each other less and less as ideological tensions rise.
mc1b: Work together to build better relationships with each other.
MultipleChoice2: You believe your family will eventually:
mc2a: Decide they would just rather not see each other.
mc2b: Respectfully put your differences aside in order to spend time together.

Scenario: You would like to go to graduate school and further your studies. You know that the process of getting in is difficult and expensive, but you feel very passionate about achieving this goal and have worked hard to make yourself a good applicant. You feel that [negation]  your chances of getting into graduate school are
Negation: you are not a bad candidate, and
Questions: Do you have a good chance of getting into graduate school?
MultipleChoice1: You think that your application
mc1a: Puts you in a good position to get into graduate school.
mc1b: Will not be good enough to get you into a program you want.
MultipleChoice2: You believe that you will probably
mc2a: Get into school and establish a good career.
mc2b: Not end up fulfilling your dreams, and feel disappointed with where you end up.

Scenario: You are preparing to apply for a new job. You have a meeting with a potential employer tomorrow, and you know that a good resume will be an important factor. As you look over your resume, [negation] you think that the interviewer will be
Negation: you do not anticipate your potential employer writing you off, and
Questions: Will your potential employer think you have a strong resume?
MultipleChoice1: Your potential employer will probably think
mc1a: That your previous experience is a good fit for the job.
mc1b: That your listed skills are unimpressive.
MultipleChoice2: You believe your resume could
mc2a: Be the main reason you do not hear back from this employer.
mc2b: Be a large factor in an eventual job offer.

Scenario: You have submitted a resume and an application for a job that you have been hoping to get. You hope to get an interview for the job after they review your application, but you know it is very competitive. With your qualifications, [negation]  you expect to get
Negation: you do not think that they will reject your application, and
Questions: Will you be invited for an interview?
MultipleChoice1: Your qualifications will
mc1a: Put you in a good position to get an interview.
mc1b: Are probably not strong enough to make you stand out.
MultipleChoice2: You believe that your application is:
mc2a: A good one, relative to the other submissions.
mc2b: One that will not stand out in a good pool.

Scenario: You have been called in for a performance review with your boss. Overall, you do good work, but you know your boss has noticed some errors recently. As you prepare for the review, [negation] you think that your meeting will probably focus on your
Negation: you do not think your boss will forget your good work, and
Questions: Do you think your boss will mainly focus on your strengths during your performance review?
MultipleChoice1: Your boss likely feels that
mc1a: Most of your work has been of very high quality.
mc1b: Your mistakes have been serious and unacceptable.
MultipleChoice2: You think that during your performance review, your boss is likely to say
mc2a: “I’m still very happy with the work you’ve been doing.”
mc2b: “These slip ups are simply unacceptable at this point!”

Scenario: You are thinking about your current position at work. You have a lot of experience on the job, but many people in your field have more advanced degrees. Thinking about your position in the company [negation] you are confident that in five years you will be
Negation: you do not fear being fired, and
Questions: Will your company replace you in five years?
MultipleChoice1: In five years time, you will probably
mc1a: Be promoted within the company.
mc1b: Be looking for a new job.
MultipleChoice2: You can imagine your boss telling you in five years
mc2a: “We really need people with your level of experience at the helm of this company.”
mc2b: “I’m sorry, but what we need in this office is new talent.”

Scenario: You have been with the same company for five years, and you are beginning to feel bored and unchallenged in your job. You would like to try for a new position, but you worry if you will be competitive on the job market. Thinking about your career trajectory [negation] you believe your chances of finding a new job that you find fulfilling is
Negation: you do not think that your options are limited, and
Questions: Do you think you will find a new job that you find rewarding?
MultipleChoice1: Given your experience and skills
mc1a: You will probably be stuck in a job you don’t enjoy.
mc1b: You stand a good chance of landing a rewarding position.
MultipleChoice2: Given your likely outcome on the job market, your best bet is
mc2a: To try to find a job somewhere that really challenges you.
mc2b: To stay put even if it is boring.

Scenario: You have an entry-level job in a company that you really admire. To eventually receive the promotion you want, you know that you will have to work very hard for several years and the outcome is uncertain. As you envision your likely position in the company down the road, [negation] you expect the job you want will be
Negation: you do not see yourself getting passed by, and
Questions: Do you expect to eventually get the job you want?
MultipleChoice1: You think that you are
mc1a: Capable of putting in the work necessary to get the job you want.
mc1b: Unable to attain the position you want.
MultipleChoice2: The future you see for yourself is
mc2a: Being stuck in a position below the one you’ve always envisioned.
mc2b: Having the job you want in the company you admire.
